Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Wings versus Legs: Mechanistic Underpinnings of Variation in Locomotor Behavior among Birds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Among the 10,000 species of living birds and their extinct dinosaurian ancestors, the relative size of, and investment in wings versus legs varies dramatically. This variation probably has profound effects on locomotor performance and many related aspects of bird ecology, including habitat preferences, foraging strategies, migration patterns, and parental care. In an effort to understand the ecological ramifications of how wings and legs function independently and cooperatively during development and evolution, the investigators will measure wing and leg morphology and locomotor performance in Australian brush turkeys (Alectura lathami) throughout their development. These data will be compared to previous studies we have conducted with two species having different patterns of locomotor development [mallard ducks (Anas platyrhynchos) and chukar partridges (Alectoris chukar)], and these comparisons will provide new insight into leg and wing structure and the mechanics of movement in juvenile and adult birds.

This project integrates the approaches of several biological disciplines and so the result will be broadly significant. This project will train undergraduate students in principles of scientific investigation. In addition, the investigators will disseminate their result to the public by making presentations to several groups (Montana Audobon Society, Upward Bound, the Society of Environmental Journalists, the Montana Girl Scouts) and to popular media outlets (History Channel, National Geographic).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit. Among the 10,000 species of living birds and their extinct dinosaurian ancestors, relative musculoskeletal investment in wings versus legs is highly diverse, varying both across species and throughout development. Such variation likely has profound effects on locomotor performance and many related aspects of bird ecology, including habitat preferences, foraging strategies, migration patterns, and parental care. In an effort to understand the ecological ramifications of how wings and legs function independently and cooperatively during development and evolution, we measured wing versus leg investment, performance and relative use – both across species, and during development in three species with different ecologies (Chukar Partridges (Alectoris chukar), Peafowl (Pavo cristatus), Mallard Ducks (Anas platyrhynchos; data from T. Dial)). Our results suggest that tradeoffs between wings and legs help shape developmental and evolutionary trajectories, but can be offset by recruiting wings and legs cooperatively (simultaneously) (Evolution, in press). For example, across species, birds with higher wing investment tend to have lower leg investment, and this apparent tradeoff in investment seems to translate to tradeoffs in both performance and behavior. Similarly, during development, juveniles with higher wing investment and performance have lower leg investment and performance, either when compared to adult counterparts or to other juveniles. These tradeoffs can be overcome at the whole body level by recruiting wings and legs cooperatively (jumping to takeoff, flap-rowing across water, etc.). Our findings offer a new paradigm for exploring locomotor strategies of flying organisms and their extinct precursors, and thereby elucidating some of the most spectacular diversity in animal history.

 

Broader impacts. This project involved an integrative series of experiments investigating potential tradeoffs between wings and legs in birds. By collaborating with biologists, paleontologists, and students, and by presenting findings to diverse audiences, our research illustrates the power of multidisciplinary approaches and encourages collaboration between scientists from diverse fields. This work has (i) involved and helped train undergraduate students in principles of scientific investigation (work of 6 students has resulted in publication and a presentation at the National Conference on Undergraduate Research),  (ii) been presented to diverse scientific audiences (Society of Integrative and Comparative Biology meetings, Society of Vertebrate Paleontology meetings, International Congress of Vertebrate Morphology meeting), and (iii) been made accessible to the public through outreach events (presentations by AMH to Montana Audobon Society, Upward Bound, Society of Environmental Journalists, Montana Girl Scouts) and popular media channels (History Channel, National Geographic).
